quotes.topic_title: Opening insight: why B2B deals end no-decision
quotes.text: 40 to 60% of B2B purchase processes end in no decision.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A striking data point that reframes the core problem as no-decision rather than losing to competitors.

quotes.topic_title: Opening insight: why B2B deals end no-decision
quotes.text: In fact, the majority of those is they couldn't figure out how to make a choice confidently.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Highlights that the main blocker is buyer uncertainty, implying pitches must build decision confidence, not just preference.

quotes.topic_title: Opening insight: why B2B deals end no-decision
quotes.text: So what they did was they just went to their boss and said, "You know what? Now's not a good time. Let's not do it now. Let's do it next year. Let's just delay it."
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of how no-decision manifests internally, useful for anticipating and countering delay narratives.

quotes.topic_title: Opening insight: why B2B deals end no-decision
quotes.text: Because that is the safe risk-free thing for that person who's on the hook to make the decision to do.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Explains the risk-avoidance incentive behind delay, suggesting sales messaging should reduce perceived personal risk of deciding.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The book guides you through a better way to pitch and sell your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Sets a practical, process-oriented promise: pitching and selling can be improved via a structured approach.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: April shares the framework that she has seen work most often in getting potential customers to get excited about your product and to decide to buy your product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights that the episode will focus on a repeatable framework tied to customer excitement and purchase decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Like I say, at the top of this episode, you'll become better at pitching and selling your product by the end of this episode.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear outcome statement that frames the segment as skill-building rather than just discussion.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Composer is the first ever algorithmic trading platform where you don't need any coding experience.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 1
quotes.context: Highlights a key adoption lever—removing technical barriers—to make algorithmic trading accessible to non-coders.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Composer also has a powerful back tester to see the historical performance of your strategies, and you can then invest with a single click.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 1
quotes.context: Actionable workflow: validate a strategy with backtesting before deploying capital, reducing guesswork.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With $1 billion in trading volume and over 1 million trades executed, composer already has many big time investors using the platform regularly.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 1
quotes.context: Provides concrete traction metrics that signal product-market fit and credibility.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This leads to wasted time building internal tools or trying to run your own experiments through a clunky marketing tool.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 1
quotes.context: Calls out a common operational failure mode in experimentation programs that teams can proactively avoid.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo lets you go beyond basic click through metrics and instead use your north star metrics like activation, retention, subscription and payments.
quotes.speaker: Speaker 1
quotes.context: A practical measurement principle: optimize experiments against business outcomes rather than shallow engagement metrics.

quotes.topic_title: Return guest welcome and episode goals
quotes.text: The secret is a lot of work.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A blunt reminder that sustainable growth comes from consistent effort, not hacks—useful for setting realistic expectations for building an audience or product.

quotes.topic_title: Return guest welcome and episode goals
quotes.text: So in order to test that positioning, what we want to do is take the positioning and translate it into a sales pitch and then test it live with prospects.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A practical methodology: validate positioning by operationalizing it into a pitch and pressure-testing it in real sales conversations.

quotes.topic_title: Return guest welcome and episode goals
quotes.text: generally what we're working on is a shift in the positioning, which is a little bit of a shift in our thinking around, how do we win in the market?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A positioning mental model that frames the work as redefining the “how we win” strategy, not just messaging tweaks.

quotes.topic_title: Why most SaaS pitches fail: feature tours
quotes.text: The sales pitch was essentially a product exposition, so essentially a glorified product box room. If there was five dropdown menus, we're going to click on all five dropdown menus and show everybody everything just feature, feature, feature, feature, feature.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Diagnoses a common SaaS pitch failure mode: defaulting to exhaustive feature tours instead of making a case for why the product wins.

quotes.topic_title: Why most SaaS pitches fail: feature tours
quotes.text: And so what I wanted to do was build a pitch structure that would reflect the positioning.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Offers a practical methodology: translate positioning into a structured pitch rather than treating the pitch as a generic demo.

quotes.topic_title: Why most SaaS pitches fail: feature tours
quotes.text: And when we're talking about features, we shouldn't be talking about features. We should be talking about the value that the features deliver.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for practitioners: shift pitch language from feature descriptions to customer value outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Why most SaaS pitches fail: feature tours
quotes.text: Help Scout said, "Well, you know what? Customer service for that kind of business is really important. It's the only time you ever get to interact with actual customers."
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Concrete example of positioning: reframing customer service as a critical customer touchpoint for digital businesses.

quotes.topic_title: Why most SaaS pitches fail: feature tours
quotes.text: And so the data shows that if you give them a really great interaction in service, it improves loyalty, it improves repeat purchases, and it's actually a growth driver. Now, most folks in other industries see customer service as a cost center.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Counterintuitive positioning backed by a data claim: customer service can be a growth driver, not just a cost center.

quotes.topic_title: Help Scout example: positioning-led pitch vs demo
quotes.text: The problem with that pitch is the customer's sitting there going, "I don't know, man, that sounds a little bit like my shared inbox, but it also sounds like help desk software. Is it different than help desk software? I'm not so sure. And there's overlap in the features there."
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Explains the core failure mode of feature-led demos: they blur differentiation and create confusion versus alternatives.

quotes.topic_title: Help Scout example: positioning-led pitch vs demo
quotes.text: And so it doesn't really answer the question, why pick us over the other guys?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A crisp diagnostic for evaluating any pitch: whether it clearly justifies selection over competitors.

quotes.topic_title: Help Scout example: positioning-led pitch vs demo
quotes.text: And so a different style of pitch would be one, we would do a little bit of setup to give everybody an idea about how we fit amongst all the other solutions and what our point of view is in the market. And then when we get to exploring the features, we would do that within the context of the differentiated value.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Defines a positioning-led pitch structure: market framing first, then features mapped to differentiated value.

quotes.topic_title: Help Scout example: positioning-led pitch vs demo
quotes.text: Now, at that point, the customer is either with you or you're not. But if they are, then we switch to the actual demo part.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Introduces a practical gating step: earn alignment on the narrative before spending time on the demo.

quotes.topic_title: Help Scout example: positioning-led pitch vs demo
quotes.text: That pitch is designed to answer the question, "Why pick us over the other folks?"
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Summarizes the purpose of the positioning-led approach as a differentiation engine, not a feature tour.

quotes.topic_title: Sales pitch framework: setup and follow-through
quotes.text: So first of all, the pitch structure has two big pieces. So the first is the setup. The setup piece is not about us, it's about the market, our point of view on the market. The second bit is all about our differentiated value. So why pick us over the other guys?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Defines a clear two-part sales pitch framework that reorients the opener around the market before moving to differentiation.

quotes.topic_title: Sales pitch framework: setup and follow-through
quotes.text: So those pieces aren't equal. In a normal sales pitch situation, we don't want to spend all day in the setup part. We want to get to the meat, which is our differentiated value, but we can't skip that bit.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Gives practical guidance on time allocation: keep setup brief but mandatory to make differentiation land.

quotes.topic_title: Sales pitch framework: setup and follow-through
quotes.text: And we could break the upfront into three pieces. So it starts with our insight into the market. So you can think of this as our point of view on the market or kind of like the problem inside the problem, in some ways.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Introduces a repeatable setup methodology and a memorable mental model (“the problem inside the problem”).

quotes.topic_title: Sales pitch framework: setup and follow-through
quotes.text: What we want to do is paint a picture of the entire market and talk about what's good and bad of the other ways of approaching the job.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Actionable instruction to explicitly frame alternatives (pros/cons) to shape how buyers evaluate your solution.

quotes.topic_title: Sales pitch framework: setup and follow-through
quotes.text: But just kind of like can we agree that if we really wanted to solve this problem and knowing what works and doesn't work in the alternate solutions, can we agree really good solutions should tick these boxes? This is getting the customer aligned with your worldview.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Shows how to use a “perfect world” conclusion to align evaluation criteria before presenting your product.

quotes.topic_title: Handling objections and using discovery correctly
quotes.text: And so if you've got a point of view on the world and you're talking to a customer that just fundamentally doesn't agree with that... In the case of a Help Scout, they come in and they say, "No, actually it's a cost center for us. We're just trying to get the cost down." They should disqualify that deal because they can't serve that customer better than Zendesk does. Zendesk is going to win that deal.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A clear rule for disqualifying misaligned prospects early, illustrated with a concrete Help Scout vs. Zendesk example.

quotes.topic_title: Handling objections and using discovery correctly
quotes.text: But if you've done this properly, your insight should resonate for the target account that you're trying to go after.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A positioning litmus test: if the core insight doesn’t resonate, you may be targeting the wrong accounts (or your insight is wrong).

quotes.topic_title: Handling objections and using discovery correctly
quotes.text: But the objections are more on a level of, if I can get you hooked at the beginning in this setup, then we go to the value, which is just proving I can do what we already agreed we wanted to get done. Then the objections tend to be more like operational stuff.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A practical sequencing model: align on insight first so later objections shift from “why” to “how.”

quotes.topic_title: Handling objections and using discovery correctly
quotes.text: And so that setup part should not be me talking at you. It should be a conversation between me and the client saying, "Do you agree with this? Is this what you're seeing? Did you start with a shared inbox? What are you doing right now? Did you ever consider using help desk software? Why yes, why no? Do you have any constraints on what you're looking at? What have you tried before? What are you looking at trying right now?"
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A concrete discovery script embedded into the pitch setup, making alignment explicit instead of assumed.

quotes.topic_title: Handling objections and using discovery correctly
quotes.text: Typically, one of the things we don't have in the pitch decks that I see in SaaS companies is there's no good place to do this discovery. So it kind of happens outside of the structure of the pitch. In this pitch structure, there's a definite spot for discovery.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A structural critique and fix: design the deck so discovery is part of the pitch, not a separate preamble.

quotes.topic_title: Teaching buyers the market to reduce overwhelm
quotes.text: What I don't have is a clear picture of the market. What are the different approaches to this problem? Forget about products. What are the approaches to the problem? Where do the products fit in those approaches? What's a good solution for me look like? What should be my purchase criteria?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A crisp articulation of the buyer’s real gap—market understanding and decision criteria—highlighting what sales should teach beyond product features.

quotes.topic_title: Teaching buyers the market to reduce overwhelm
quotes.text: But if you look at the research on this stuff, the research doesn't support that. The research actually says what B2B software buyers want in a sales interaction is perspectives on the market and help weighing their options. And we don't do that.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that buyers want vendor-led market perspective, challenging the fear that discussing options reduces trust.

quotes.topic_title: Teaching buyers the market to reduce overwhelm
quotes.text: And so the data on this shows that for B2B, 40 to 60% of B2B purchase processes end in no decision.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A key data point that frames indecision—not losing to competitors—as a major outcome sales must actively prevent.

quotes.topic_title: Teaching buyers the market to reduce overwhelm
quotes.text: The old thing we were doing is better, that's not true at all. In fact, the majority of those is they couldn't figure out how to make a choice confidently.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Reframes “no decision” as a confidence problem rather than satisfaction with the status quo, implying sales should reduce decision risk.

quotes.topic_title: Teaching buyers the market to reduce overwhelm
quotes.text: So what we should be doing is giving them a way to think about the whole market and say, in the case of Help Scout, "Look, there's shared inbox and then there's help desk software and then there's us. And I don't care who the vendor is, I'm going to put them in one of those buckets."
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A concrete, reusable method: teach a simple market map (buckets) so buyers can categorize options and decide with less overwhelm.

quotes.topic_title: No-decision drivers and why FOMO backfires
quotes.text: we lose an awful lot of deals to just plain customer indecision, customers being more afraid of screwing up than missing out.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Reframes “status quo” losses as often driven by fear of making the wrong decision rather than lack of need.

quotes.topic_title: No-decision drivers and why FOMO backfires
quotes.text: they studied two and a half million sales calls, they recorded on Gong and they studied it with AI, and then they looked at what happened after the sales call, so were these successful or not successful, did a deal happen or whatever.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Grounds the discussion in unusually large-scale empirical evidence about what actually moves deals.

quotes.topic_title: No-decision drivers and why FOMO backfires
quotes.text: what his data showed is if a customer is indecisive, throwing FOMO into the mix makes it worse.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Counterintuitive finding: urgency/FOMO can reduce close rates when the real blocker is decision paralysis.

quotes.topic_title: No-decision drivers and why FOMO backfires
quotes.text: So what does work in that situation is, one, giving them the tools to make the decision.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Actionable prescription: shift from pressure tactics to decision enablement to reduce buyer stress.

quotes.topic_title: No-decision drivers and why FOMO backfires
quotes.text: So this idea of being able to take risk off the table is a really serious one if we've got a customer that is actually paralyzed because of this indecision thing.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Provides a practical framework—risk reduction (guarantees, support, smaller steps)—to unblock no-decision outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Champion’s job: decide safely without getting fired
quotes.text: And so one of the things I think of is normally when we come at this we're like, "Well, how can we convince the customer that we do the job that they need to have done?" And obviously we need to do that, but there is this secondary job that the champion of the deal is, and that's how do I make a decision without getting fired? And so we got to help them accomplish that job, otherwise we don't get what we want, which is the money.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Reframes the buyer champion’s real “job” as making a defensible decision, not just choosing the best product.

quotes.topic_title: Champion’s job: decide safely without getting fired
quotes.text: And this FOMO thing is just not going to do it.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Challenges the common tactic of using urgency/FOMO by implying it doesn’t address the buyer’s need for safety.

quotes.topic_title: Champion’s job: decide safely without getting fired
quotes.text: Well, this is the thing, it's so easy to default to the market leader in that situation. The market leader has this big advantage that you can say, "You know what? Who's going to get me in trouble for picking Salesforce? Nobody." It's so easy to just flip back on that. And so if you're the challenger in this situation, the brand that's number two or number three, you've got to get over all of this inertia and tilting towards the status quo, because it's just so easy, it's the lowest risk decision, besides do nothing is to just pick the leader in the market and we'll just run with that.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Explains why incumbents win on perceived safety and what challengers must overcome: inertia toward the lowest-risk choice.

quotes.topic_title: Champion’s job: decide safely without getting fired
quotes.text: And you start with I just wanted the best community forum software because we were trying to build something really different and unique and you end up with like, "Okay, it's fine, just go with the thing that works with Salesforce. It's all good. I'm just going to move on to another process."
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete enterprise buying story showing how “best product” decisions get overridden by integration and risk-reduction pressures.

quotes.topic_title: Multi-stakeholder B2B buying and arming champions
quotes.text: Now, the other people can't make a deal happen, but they can kill it a thousand ways.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A crisp mental model for multi-stakeholder B2B buying: most stakeholders are veto players, so you must proactively de-risk their objections.

quotes.topic_title: Multi-stakeholder B2B buying and arming champions
quotes.text: So the way this works is your positioning and your pitch needs to really work for the champion, because if it doesn't, you don't even get to talk to anybody else, you don't even get to go near anybody else if you don't make it out of the shortlist and you don't get the deal cooking.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on sequencing: win the champion first to earn access and momentum before worrying about the rest of the committee.

quotes.topic_title: Multi-stakeholder B2B buying and arming champions
quotes.text: But once the deal is cooking it is on you to arm that champion to handle all the objections potentially of all the other groups.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A practical methodology: shift from persuasion to enablement by equipping the champion with objection-handling assets for each stakeholder group.

quotes.topic_title: Multi-stakeholder B2B buying and arming champions
quotes.text: and IT doesn't really care about the value of your CRM, but they do care does it meet the security requirements and does it integrate with the stuff we already have and how much of a pain is this thing going to be to manage, and so we're not actually pitching value to those people, we're just handling objections.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Counterintuitive reminder that different stakeholders aren’t persuaded by the same “value” story—many just need risk/effort objections resolved.

quotes.topic_title: Multi-stakeholder B2B buying and arming champions
quotes.text: Well, if we're really smart, we already know because we've done lots of deals.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: A concrete standard for sales discovery: anticipate predictable stakeholder concerns from prior deals instead of relying only on asking in the moment.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the framework in early-stage companies
quotes.text: Second thing is that I've worked with tons of companies where the founder is the only sales rep and this works pretty good for that.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Validates that the framework applies even in very early-stage companies where the founder is doing all selling.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the framework in early-stage companies
quotes.text: I don't think we need a ton of resources to do it, but I do think we need to have enough traction in the market that we understand how a deal typically goes.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Sets a practical prerequisite: you don’t need headcount, but you do need real deal experience to model the buying process.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the framework in early-stage companies
quotes.text: But if I've done 10 deals, I know what happens, I got a pretty good guess of what IT is going to say when you try to implement this stuff, I have a good guess of what's going to happen when we go to roll it out, I have a pretty good guess of what your boss might object to or might get excited by.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Offers a concrete heuristic (“10 deals”) for when you have enough signal to anticipate objections and tailor the pitch.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the framework in early-stage companies
quotes.text: This is just me trying to be helpful and help the champion do their job of getting this deal to the finish line.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Reframes sales enablement as equipping the internal champion to navigate implementation and stakeholder objections.

quotes.topic_title: Product, marketing, and sales alignment on value
quotes.text: the core of a good sales pitch is really deeply understanding your differentiated value, which is what is the value I can deliver that no other solution can.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Defines the foundational mental model for building a sales pitch around unique value rather than generic benefits.

quotes.topic_title: Product, marketing, and sales alignment on value
quotes.text: the first step in fixing this I think is to have a cross-functional team work on positioning.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, actionable starting point for aligning product, marketing, and sales on value.

quotes.topic_title: Product, marketing, and sales alignment on value
quotes.text: So if I've got product, marketing, and sales together in the room working on defining what our differentiated value is, then I'm going to get all the good juice out of the product team that deeply understands the product, deeply understand what's differentiated about it, deeply understands value, and then I'm also going to have all the juice from the sales team that understands what the common objections are, what the champion really wants to get done and doesn't want to get done, what the situation is in a typical account, and then all of this cool information sharing happens, which actually you end up with way better definition of your differentiated value in the first place.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Explains the cross-functional methodology and why combining product knowledge with sales objections improves positioning quality.

quotes.topic_title: Product, marketing, and sales alignment on value
quotes.text: Marketing in their own little bubble comes up with positioning, they might build some stuff for the sales team, heave it over to the sales team. Sales team looks at it and says, "I don't get what any of this stuff is. I disagree with this. This doesn't match what I see," and they just throw it out and they go back to doing the same pitch they've been doing since the year of the flood.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode where siloed positioning work gets rejected by sales and never changes the pitch.

quotes.topic_title: Defining differentiated value with examples
quotes.text: Yeah. So differentiated value is the answer to the question why pick us over the other alternatives?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Defines differentiated value in a simple, decision-oriented way that can anchor positioning and pitch work.

quotes.topic_title: Defining differentiated value with examples
quotes.text: And so the way we get at that in positioning is we start with putting a stake in the ground of who do we actually compete with? And so if we didn't exist in the market, what would a customer do?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Gives a practical method for identifying true competitive alternatives, including status quo options.

quotes.topic_title: Defining differentiated value with examples
quotes.text: And then what we do is we go down that list of features and we say, "So what? You got advanced AI, whatever the heck the thing is, so what? Why does anybody care?" And the answer to that so what is your value.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Introduces the repeatable “so what” chain to translate features into customer value that matters in a pitch.

quotes.topic_title: Defining differentiated value with examples
quotes.text: If you look at LevelJump, they're differentiated capability is they're the only one that's built on top of Salesforce.
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Concrete example of a differentiated capability that can be traced through to measurable business outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Defining differentiated value with examples
quotes.text: It does. It absolutely is. The insight is basically the context that makes your differentiated value important, what is the thing you need to know to understand the importance of my differentiated value?
quotes.speaker: April Dunford
quotes.context: Clarifies how “insight” functions in a sales pitch: it sets up why the differentiated value matters.
